summary: This document is an email chain from September 2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel discussing technical difficulties in providing discovery materials to Ghislaine Maxwell while she is incarcerated at MDC Brooklyn. The emails focus on converting various file types (.xls, .eml, .txt, audio/video files, and others) into formats viewable on the limited computers at the detention center.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the emails; she is incarcerated at MDC Brooklyn and needs software to review discovery materials in various file formats.

persons.name: Jeff
persons.context: Mentioned as someone who will be asked to confirm the nature of certain system-generated files in the discovery materials.

connections.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office is prosecuting Maxwell and is corresponding about providing her with discovery materials.

events.title: Initial request for viewing software
events.description: A paralegal specialist emails colleagues about Maxwell's issues viewing discovery files due to lack of software for .xls, .eml, .txt, and audio/video files.

events.title: Follow-up on file conversion issues
events.description: Further emails detail specific problematic file extensions from various productions and discuss solutions for converting them for Maxwell to review at MDC.

locations: U.S. Attorney's Office, SDNY, 1 St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell was incarcerated at MDC Brooklyn in September 2020 and was actively reviewing discovery materials for her case.

The U.S. Attorney's Office was assisting Maxwell in accessing discovery by attempting to convert various file types (.xls, .eml, .txt, audio/video, and others) to formats compatible with MDC's limited computers.
The emails reference specific discovery productions (e.g., PRODUCTION 2, PRODUCTION 3) containing numerous file types, indicating a large volume of digital evidence.
Technical challenges included MDC computers lacking software to open basic file types like Microsoft Excel (.xls) files.
The correspondence shows logistical efforts by the prosecution to facilitate Maxwell's review of discovery while she was in pretrial detention.
